sentence: Friday headlines include: Earnings from Amazon, Ford and Microsoft; Procter & Gamble splitting off Duracell and Pfizer authorizing a giant share repurchase.
Online retailer Amazon ( AMZN ) said Thursday that it lost 95 cents per share in the third quarter on $20.6 billion in revenue.
Analysts had expected the company to lose about 74 cents per share.
Looking forward, the company said it expects revenue of $27.3 billion and $30.3 billion in the fourth quarter, short of estimates for $30.9 billion.
Consumer goods giant Procter & Gamble ( PG ) said Friday that it would split Duracell into a separate company as part of move to focus on faster-growing brands.
The company also said it earned 69 cents per share on an adjusted basis in the third quarter, on $20.79 billion in sales.
On a GAAP basis, the company said it earned $1.07 per share.
Drugmaker Pfizer ( PFE ) said Friday that its board approved an $11 billion plan to repurchase the company's common stock.

The repurchases could keep the stock at or above its current level, but likely means the company is not in the market for a big acquisition, such as a re-ignition of its flirtation with AstraZeneca ( AZN ).
Automaker Ford (F ) said Friday that it earned 21 cents per share in the third quarter or 24 cents per share on an adjusted basis.
Analysts had expected the company to earn 19 cents per share.
Revenue was $34.9 billion in the quarter, down 3%, which the company said was because its F-150 plant is closed for retooling ahead of the launch of a new, aluminum-bodied truck.
Software giant Microsoft ( MSFT ) said Thursday that it earned 54 cents per share, or 44 cents per share not including a one-time charge.
Analysts had expected the company to earn 49 cents per share, including the charge.
Revenue was $23.2 billion, compared to estimates for $22 billion.
